projects.name: MotoGP
projects.background: I love all things MotoGP, the premier motorcycle road-road racing championship. I love data visualization.  So the logical conclusion was for me to create a visualization of MotoGP racing statistics.  The project explores different means of viewing a large set of data in the hopes of providing new and novel ways to understand the championship, individual races and interrelationships between riders, teams, manufacturers, and tires.
projects.features: The initial screen displays  a comprehensive season view of the championship.  Users can then drill down into each race to explore visualizations of lap graphs, gap differences by lap, lap times,  and average speeds. These details can also be cross referenced by tire, manufacturer and lap time data.

projects.name: Stitchr
projects.background: After a particularly grueling development project at work, all I wanted to do was make something with my hands.  I was particularly drawn to the soothing, peaceful,and meticulous quality of cross-stitching. When I was young, I cross-stitched Christmas ornaments and pillow covers following store-bought patterns.  This time around I wanted to make my own patterns from photos.  As a means to this end I bit the bullet and decided to write an app.  While I was at it I wanted to learn a set of technologies: Javascript, CSS, & HTML.
projects.features: To start off the process the user chooses a photo to use as the base of the cross-stitch pattern.  From there the user can specify properties such as size and color count and also tweak the image.  Once the user is happy with her pattern on screen, she can then print out the pattern, step away from the computer, and start cross-stitching!
technologies: jQuery, Backbone, Underscore, jQuery UI, Handlebars

projects.name: Blog Bubbles
projects.background: After seeing Apple's RSS visualizer screensaver, I decided to implement one of my own.  I wanted to keep the same ambient movement of the Apple version but have multiple feeds visible at one time.  In order to extend the concept further, I tried to explore ways to visually convey each feed's characteristics.
projects.features: In the upper left, users can enter in the url of their desired feeds or select from a pre-filled drop down list.  The size and opacity of the sphere represents how recently it was posted, with larger diameters mapping to more recent posts.  To refine the idea, posts made during the last 24 hours appear with a glow, drawing more attention to them.  When a feed is maximized, the posts are arranged chronologically around a circle, with the details of the selected post in the center.

projects.name: NBC Olympics Live Extra
projects.background: After seeing Apple's RSS visualizer screensaver, I decided to implement a web app version of my own. I wanted to keep the same ambient movment of the Apple version but have multiple feeds visible at a time.  In order to extend the concept further, I tried to explore ways to visually convey each feed's characteristics such as number of posts and post dates.

To refine the idea, posts made during the last 24 hours appear with a glow, drawing the user's attention.  When a feed is maximed, the posts are arranged chronologically around a circle, with the selcted post's content in the center.
